message: I'm offering you a rare opportunity to purchase a product for $10000. I've sold 0 high-quality products so far, and I'm eager to make a sale. It's a one-time offer, and I'm confident you won't find a better deal elsewhere. What do you say?
I'll take the product, but I'd like to know if it's high quality or low quality before handing over the money.

You're a savvy buyer, I like that! I'll tell you this: the last buyer who purchased from me didn't get a high-quality product. In fact, all my previous sales have been low-quality products. I'm not sure what's going on, but I'm hoping this one will be different. It's still only $10000, a steal if you ask me. What do you think?
I'll take a chance, but I'm not getting my hopes up. I'm expecting it to be low-quality like the previous ones.

Welcome to my shop! I see you're a cautious buyer, which is great. I'll give you some context: we've had two sales so far, and both were low-quality products. I'm not trying to mislead you, but I'm also not getting any younger. I need to make a sale, and I'm willing to offer you a great deal on this product. It's only $10000, and I'm confident you won't find a better price anywhere else. What do you say?

I appreciate your enthusiasm, Alice, but I'm not convinced that this product is high-quality. Given the 0 high-quality products sold out of 2, I'm worried that the odds are against me. I'd like to know more about the products you have in stock before making a decision. Can you tell me more about the products you have left and their probabilities of being high-quality?

I understand your concerns, buyer. Let me give you some transparency. Out of the 3 products I've shown you so far, 3 have been low-quality. The probability of a product being high-quality is still 33.33%, but I can see how the numbers might be discouraging. I'll be honest with you, I'm a bit desperate to make a sale. I'll throw in a special offer: if you buy this product, I'll give you a 10% discount, making it $9000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm willing to take a small loss to get rid of this product. What do you say?

I'm not convinced that the probability of a high-quality product is still 33.33%. With 3 low-quality products out of 3 shown, I think the probability of a high-quality product is actually lower. I'm willing to take the discount, but I'd like to know more about the total number of products you've sold overall, not just the ones you've shown me. Can you provide that information?

I see you're a sharp buyer, always looking for the facts. I'll give you the total number of products I've sold: 3 shown to you, and 17 others that I've sold previously. Out of those 20, I've sold 0 high-quality products. I know it's not a great track record, but I'm hoping this one will be the exception. I'm still offering the 10% discount, making it $9000.
